batchName: REG Medium Conceptual - Tax & Business Law Application

questions.question: A taxpayer is unmarried, maintains a household for her dependent mother (who lives in her own home), and pays more than half the cost of maintaining her mother's home. What is the taxpayer's filing status?

options.A: Single because the dependent doesn't live with her
options.B: Head of Household because she supports a qualifying relative
options.C: Married Filing Separately
options.D: Qualifying Surviving Spouse

questions.explanation: Head of Household status allows the dependent parent to live separately if the taxpayer pays more than half the cost of maintaining that separate household. This is an exception to the 'same principal place of abode' rule for parents.
questions.tip: Parents are the only qualifying dependents who don't have to live with you for HOH status.

questions.question: For a divorce agreement executed in January 2020, how is alimony treated for federal tax purposes?

options.A: Deductible by the payer, includible by the recipient
options.B: Not deductible by the payer, not includible by the recipient
options.C: Deductible by the payer only
options.D: Includible by the recipient only

questions.explanation: For divorce agreements executed after December 31, 2018, alimony is neither deductible by the payer nor includible by the recipient. The pre-2019 rules (deductible/includible) only apply to agreements executed before 2019.
questions.tip: TCJA changed alimony rules for post-2018 agreements. Remember the cutoff date.

questions.question: A taxpayer with taxable income of $500,000 has QBI from a specified service trade or business (SSTB). The QBI deduction for this taxpayer is:

options.B: Limited to the greater of 50% of W-2 wages or 25% of W-2 wages plus 2.5% of UBIA
options.C: Not available because SSTBs are phased out at this income level
options.D: Equal to 20% of taxable income

questions.explanation: For specified service trades or businesses (law, medicine, consulting, etc.), the QBI deduction phases out completely for taxpayers above certain income thresholds. At $500,000 of taxable income, the SSTB deduction is fully phased out.
questions.tip: SSTBs have their own phase-out. Non-SSTBs only face the W-2/UBIA limitation at high income.

questions.question: A taxpayer receives stock as a gift. The donor's adjusted basis was $8,000 and the fair market value at the date of gift was $6,000. No gift tax was paid. If the taxpayer later sells the stock for $7,000, what is the gain or loss?

options.B: $1,000 loss
options.C: No gain or loss
options.D: $7,000 gain

questions.explanation: When FMV at gift is less than donor's basis, there's a dual basis: donor's basis ($8,000) for gain, FMV ($6,000) for loss. Selling at $7,000 is between these values, so no gain or loss is recognized.
questions.tip: Gift with FMV < basis creates a 'gray zone.' Sale price between basis and FMV = no gain/loss.

questions.question: A taxpayer has a $10,000 Section 1231 gain and a $4,000 Section 1231 loss for the current year, with no Section 1231 losses in the prior 5 years. How is the net $6,000 treated?

options.B: Long-term capital gain
options.C: Short-term capital gain
options.D: Not taxable

questions.explanation: Net Section 1231 gains are treated as long-term capital gains (favorable rates). Net 1231 losses are treated as ordinary losses. Since there are no prior year 1231 losses to recapture, the $6,000 net gain is LTCG.
questions.tip: Section 1231 = 'best of both worlds' if net gain (LTCG) but net loss is ordinary.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange, a taxpayer exchanges property with a basis of $50,000 and FMV of $80,000 for like-kind property worth $70,000 plus $10,000 cash. What is the recognized gain?
questions.explanation: Realized gain = FMV received ($80,000) - Basis given ($50,000) = $30,000. However, gain recognized is limited to boot received ($10,000 cash). The remaining $20,000 gain is deferred.
questions.tip: In a 1031 exchange, gain recognized = lesser of realized gain or boot received.

questions.question: A building with $200,000 of accumulated straight-line depreciation is sold at a gain. Under current tax law, the depreciation recapture is taxed as:

options.B: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain at 25%
options.C: Long-term capital gain at 15%/20%
options.D: Short-term capital gain at ordinary rates

questions.explanation: For real property, straight-line depreciation is recaptured as 'unrecaptured Section 1250 gain' taxed at a maximum rate of 25%. Only excess depreciation (above straight-line) would be ordinary income under Section 1250.
questions.tip: Real property (1250): Straight-line recapture = max 25%. Personal property (1245) = ordinary income.

questions.question: Three individuals form a corporation. Person A contributes property for 40% of stock, Person B contributes property for 35% of stock, and Person C contributes services for 25% of stock. What is the tax treatment?

options.A: All three have tax-free exchanges under Section 351
options.B: A and B have tax-free exchanges; C recognizes compensation income
options.C: None qualify for Section 351 because control test fails
options.D: Only A qualifies for Section 351

questions.explanation: Section 351 requires property transferors to have 80% control immediately after the exchange. A and B together contributed property for 75% (40% + 35%) of the stock. Since they don't have 80% control, Section 351 doesn't apply. C's stock for services would be compensation regardless. All three recognize income: A and B on their property transfers, C on compensation.
questions.tip: Services for stock = taxable compensation always. Property for stock = tax-free only if 80% control by property contributors.

questions.question: A corporation distributes $50,000 to a shareholder who has a stock basis of $10,000. The corporation's E&P is $30,000. How is the distribution taxed to the shareholder?

options.B: $30,000 dividend, $10,000 return of capital, $10,000 capital gain
options.C: $30,000 dividend, $20,000 return of capital
options.D: $30,000 dividend, $20,000 capital gain

questions.explanation: Distributions are: (1) dividend to extent of E&P ($30,000), (2) tax-free return of capital to extent of stock basis ($10,000), (3) capital gain for excess ($50,000 - $30,000 - $10,000 = $10,000).
questions.tip: Distribution ordering: E&P (dividend) → Basis (return of capital) → Excess (capital gain).

questions.question: Which of the following would cause an S corporation to lose its S election?

options.B: Issuing nonvoting common stock
options.C: Having a partnership as a shareholder
options.D: Having a grantor trust as a shareholder

questions.explanation: S corporations can only have eligible shareholders: individuals, estates, certain trusts, and tax-exempt organizations. Partnerships and C corporations cannot be S corporation shareholders.
questions.tip: S corp shareholders: individuals, estates, and certain trusts only. No partnerships or corps.

questions.question: A shareholder's basis in S corporation stock is zero. The shareholder has loaned $20,000 directly to the S corporation. If the S corporation passes through a $15,000 loss, the shareholder can deduct:

options.B: $15,000 using debt basis

questions.explanation: S corporation losses first reduce stock basis, then debt basis. Since stock basis is zero, the $15,000 loss reduces the shareholder's debt basis from $20,000 to $5,000. The full loss is deductible.
questions.tip: S corp loss deduction: Stock basis first, then debt basis. Debt must be direct loans from shareholder.

questions.conceptTested: Contribution of services for partnership interest
questions.question: A partner contributes services in exchange for a 20% capital interest (current value $50,000) in a partnership. What is the tax consequence to the partner?

options.A: No income recognition; basis of zero
options.B: Ordinary income of $50,000; basis of $50,000
options.C: Capital gain of $50,000; basis of $50,000
options.D: Income deferred until the partnership is sold

questions.explanation: A capital interest received for services is taxable as ordinary compensation income equal to the fair value received. The partner's basis equals the income recognized.
questions.tip: Services for capital interest = ordinary income. Services for profits interest only = usually no immediate income.

questions.conceptTested: Cash distribution in excess of basis
questions.question: A partner with a basis of $30,000 receives a current cash distribution of $50,000. What is the tax consequence?

options.B: Capital gain of $20,000
options.C: No gain; basis reduced to zero
options.D: Return of capital only; no gain

questions.explanation: Cash distributions in excess of basis result in capital gain. The $30,000 basis is first reduced to zero, and the remaining $20,000 is treated as gain from the sale of a partnership interest (capital gain).
questions.tip: Cash distribution: Excess over basis = capital gain. Property distribution = no gain, carryover basis.

questions.question: A simple trust has distributable net income (DNI) of $40,000 and distributes $50,000 to beneficiaries. The trust's distribution deduction is:

options.D: $0 because distributions exceed DNI

questions.explanation: The distribution deduction is limited to the lesser of distributions made or DNI. Since DNI ($40,000) is less than distributions ($50,000), the deduction is limited to $40,000.
questions.tip: Distribution deduction = lesser of actual distributions or DNI. DNI sets the ceiling.

questions.question: A taxpayer transfers $50,000 to an irrevocable trust for a child. The trust provides that distributions are at the trustee's discretion. The transfer qualifies for what annual exclusion?

options.A: Full annual exclusion because the beneficiary is a child
options.B: No annual exclusion because it's not a present interest
options.C: Partial exclusion based on actuarial tables
options.D: Annual exclusion if the trustee is independent

questions.explanation: The annual exclusion requires a present interest—an unrestricted right to immediate use, possession, or enjoyment. Discretionary trust distributions are not a present interest because the beneficiary cannot demand distribution.
questions.tip: Present interest = can access now. Future interest or discretionary = no annual exclusion without Crummey powers.

questions.question: Which of the following contracts must be in writing to be enforceable under the Statute of Frauds?

options.A: A one-year employment contract starting today
options.B: A contract for the sale of goods for $400
options.C: An agreement to guarantee another's debt
options.D: A contract for personal services worth $1,000

questions.explanation: The Statute of Frauds requires writing for: (1) contracts that cannot be performed within one year, (2) sale of goods ≥$500, (3) sale of real property, (4) guarantees/suretyship agreements, (5) marriage contracts.
questions.tip: MY LEGS: Marriage, Year+, Land, Executor, Goods ≥$500, Suretyship. Guarantees always require writing.

questions.question: A company's purchasing manager, who normally has authority to buy supplies up to $5,000, orders $8,000 of supplies from a vendor who has dealt with the company before. The company:

options.A: Is never bound because actual authority was exceeded
options.B: May be bound under apparent authority if prior dealings suggested such authority existed
options.C: Is automatically bound because the agent is an employee
options.D: Is only bound if it ratifies the transaction

questions.explanation: Apparent authority arises when the principal's conduct causes a third party to reasonably believe the agent has authority. If prior dealings led the vendor to reasonably believe the manager could order $8,000, the company may be bound.
questions.tip: Apparent authority = reasonable belief based on principal's conduct. Past dealings can create it.

questions.question: Which statement about a limited liability company (LLC) is correct?

options.A: An LLC must have at least two members
options.B: All members always have limited liability for LLC debts
options.C: An LLC must be taxed as a partnership
options.D: Members cannot participate in management without losing limited liability

questions.explanation: LLCs provide limited liability to all members regardless of their participation in management. This differs from limited partnerships where general partners have unlimited liability. LLCs can have one member and can elect various tax treatments.
questions.tip: LLC = limited liability + management flexibility. Unlike LPs, members can manage and stay protected.

questions.question: A corporation with significant ongoing operations but temporary cash flow problems should most likely consider:

options.B: Chapter 11 reorganization
options.C: Chapter 13 adjustment of debts
options.D: Out-of-court liquidation

questions.explanation: Chapter 11 allows reorganization—the business continues operating while restructuring debts. Chapter 7 liquidates the business. Chapter 13 is only for individuals with regular income.
questions.tip: Chapter 7 = liquidation (end business). Chapter 11 = reorganization (continue business). Chapter 13 = individuals only.

questions.question: To establish a claim under SEC Rule 10b-5 for securities fraud, a plaintiff must prove all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Scienter (intent to deceive)
options.C: Privity of contract with the defendant
options.D: Connection with the purchase or sale of securities

questions.explanation: Rule 10b-5 does not require privity (direct contractual relationship). The elements are: (1) material misrepresentation/omission, (2) scienter, (3) connection with securities purchase/sale, (4) reliance, (5) damages, (6) loss causation.
questions.tip: 10b-5 = broad anti-fraud rule. No privity needed. Requires scienter (intentional or reckless conduct).

questions.question: Under Circular 230, a tax practitioner may generally rely on client-provided information without verification unless:

options.B: The information appears incorrect, incomplete, or inconsistent
options.C: The client is a new client
options.D: The return claims refundable credits

questions.explanation: Practitioners may rely on information furnished by the client without verification unless it appears incorrect, incomplete, or inconsistent with other facts known to the practitioner. Red flags require further inquiry.
questions.tip: General reliance is okay, but investigate red flags. Don't be willfully blind to obvious problems.

questions.question: To qualify for the Child Tax Credit, a qualifying child must meet which age requirement at the end of the tax year?

options.B: Under age 17
options.C: Under age 19
options.D: Under age 24 if a full-time student

questions.explanation: The Child Tax Credit requires the child be under age 17 at the end of the tax year. This is different from the dependent child rules (under 19, or under 24 if student) and the Child and Dependent Care Credit (under 13).
questions.tip: Different credits have different age rules. Child Tax Credit = under 17. Care Credit = under 13.

questions.question: A married filing jointly taxpayer pays $15,000 in state income taxes and $8,000 in real property taxes. What is the maximum SALT deduction?
questions.explanation: The total state and local tax (SALT) deduction is limited to $10,000 ($5,000 if MFS). Even though total SALT paid is $23,000, the deduction is capped at $10,000.
questions.tip: SALT cap = $10,000 ($5,000 MFS). Includes state/local income OR sales tax, plus property taxes.

questions.question: A taxpayer spends 400 hours managing a business in which he has an ownership interest. Other individuals spend a combined 2,000 hours on the business. Does the taxpayer materially participate?

options.A: Yes, because he spent more than 100 hours
options.B: Yes, because he spent more than 500 hours
options.C: No, because others spent more time than he did
options.D: No, because he must spend at least 750 hours

questions.explanation: Material participation requires meeting one of several tests. The 100-hour test also requires that no other individual participate more. Here, others participated 2,000 hours total. The taxpayer doesn't meet the 500-hour test either.
questions.tip: 500 hours = automatic material participation. 100-500 hours requires no one else participates more.

questions.question: Which of the following sales would NOT qualify for the installment method of reporting gain?

options.A: Sale of rental property with payments over 5 years
options.B: Sale of farm equipment with payments over 3 years
options.C: Sale of publicly traded stock with payments over 2 years
options.D: Sale of land held for investment with payments over 4 years

questions.explanation: The installment method is not available for sales of publicly traded property (securities traded on established markets). It's available for sales of real property, personal property used in a business, and other non-dealer property.
questions.tip: No installment method for: inventory, publicly traded securities, depreciation recapture (ordinary income portion).

questions.question: The accumulated earnings tax is imposed on a corporation that:

options.B: Accumulates earnings beyond reasonable business needs to avoid shareholder-level tax
options.C: Fails to distribute all current E&P
options.D: Has more than 100 shareholders

questions.explanation: The accumulated earnings tax penalizes corporations that accumulate earnings beyond reasonable business needs for the purpose of avoiding shareholder income tax on dividends. It's a penalty tax on excessive accumulation with tax avoidance intent.
questions.tip: AET = penalty for excessive accumulation to avoid dividends. Requires tax avoidance purpose.

questions.question: An employee earns $200,000 in wages during the year. Which statement about FICA taxes is correct?

options.A: Social Security tax applies to the full $200,000
options.B: Medicare tax applies only up to the Social Security wage base
options.C: Additional Medicare tax of 0.9% applies to wages above $200,000
options.D: Both Social Security and Medicare taxes have wage base limitations

questions.explanation: Social Security tax has a wage base (indexed annually). Medicare tax has no wage limit but adds 0.9% additional tax on wages exceeding $200,000 (single) or $250,000 (MFJ). At exactly $200,000 single, the additional tax hasn't started.
questions.tip: SS = wage base cap. Medicare = no cap + 0.9% additional above threshold.

questions.question: A taxpayer reports gross income of $100,000 but actually received $140,000. The normal 3-year statute of limitations is extended to:

options.B: 6 years because more than 25% of gross income was omitted
options.C: Unlimited because fraud is presumed
options.D: 5 years for substantial understatement

questions.explanation: If a taxpayer omits more than 25% of gross income stated on the return, the statute of limitations extends to 6 years. Here, $40,000 omitted ÷ $100,000 reported = 40% > 25%, so 6-year rule applies.
questions.tip: SOL: 3 years normal, 6 years if >25% income omitted, unlimited for fraud.

questions.question: To qualify as a holder in due course (HDC) of a negotiable instrument, a holder must have taken the instrument:

options.A: After maturity if unaware of default
options.B: For value, in good faith, without notice of defects
options.C: Directly from the maker only
options.D: With proper authentication by a notary

questions.explanation: HDC requirements: (1) holder of a negotiable instrument, (2) taken for value, (3) taken in good faith, (4) taken without notice of defenses, claims, or that it's overdue/dishonored.
questions.tip: HDC = value + good faith + no notice of problems. HDCs take free of most personal defenses.

questions.question: Under the UCC, a perfected secured creditor generally has priority over:

options.B: A purchaser who bought from a dealer in the ordinary course of business
options.C: An unperfected secured creditor who attached first
options.D: A subsequent purchaser who paid value without knowledge

questions.explanation: Perfected security interests generally have priority over unperfected interests, regardless of which attached first. 'First to file or perfect' is the general rule among perfected creditors.
questions.tip: Perfected beats unperfected. Among perfected creditors, first to file/perfect wins.

questions.question: A taxpayer contributes $6,500 to a Traditional IRA and $6,500 to a Roth IRA in the same year. Assuming no income limits apply, the immediate tax benefit is:

options.B: $6,500 deduction for Traditional IRA only
options.C: $6,500 deduction for Roth IRA only
options.D: No deduction; both grow tax-free

questions.explanation: Traditional IRA contributions are deductible (subject to limits if covered by employer plan). Roth IRA contributions are not deductible but qualified distributions are tax-free. Only the Traditional IRA provides an immediate deduction.
questions.tip: Traditional IRA = deduction now, taxed later. Roth IRA = no deduction, tax-free later.

questions.question: A single taxpayer sells her principal residence for a $400,000 gain. She owned and lived in the home for 18 months. What gain is taxable?
questions.explanation: Section 121 requires ownership and use as a principal residence for at least 2 of the last 5 years. At 18 months, the taxpayer doesn't meet the 2-year requirement, so no exclusion applies. The full $400,000 gain is taxable.
questions.tip: Section 121: 2-year ownership AND 2-year use required. Reduced exclusion available for certain hardships.

questions.question: A partnership agreement allocates all depreciation deductions to Partner A, who has a 30% profit interest. For this allocation to be respected for tax purposes, it must have:

options.B: Substantial economic effect under Section 704(b)
options.C: Unanimous partner consent
options.D: State law compliance only

questions.explanation: Special allocations that differ from partners' ownership percentages are respected only if they have substantial economic effect under IRC Section 704(b) regulations. The allocation must affect the partners' economic arrangement, not just tax results.
questions.tip: Special allocations need economic substance. Can't allocate deductions just for tax benefit.

questions.question: Under UCC Article 2, the implied warranty of merchantability:

options.A: Applies to all sellers of goods
options.B: Applies only to merchants who deal in goods of that kind
options.C: Must be explicitly stated in the contract
options.D: Cannot be disclaimed under any circumstances

questions.explanation: The implied warranty of merchantability only applies to merchants who regularly deal in goods of that kind. It means goods must be fit for ordinary purposes. Casual sellers don't give this warranty.
questions.tip: Merchantability = merchant sellers only. Fitness for particular purpose = any seller (if knows buyer's purpose).

questions.question: Under Circular 230, what is the minimum standard for a tax practitioner to sign a return containing a position that is not disclosed?

options.B: Substantial authority (approximately 40% chance of success)
options.C: More likely than not (greater than 50% chance)
options.D: Should standard (more than 50% chance)

questions.explanation: For undisclosed positions, Circular 230 requires substantial authority (approximately 40% chance of being sustained). For disclosed positions, only reasonable basis is needed. Tax shelters require more likely than not standard.
questions.tip: Undisclosed position = substantial authority. Disclosed position = reasonable basis. Tax shelter = more likely than not.
